items.synopsis: The news Australia is searching for, and all the news that happened while you snoozed: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Trump faces questions at CNN town hall, France investigates death of journalist in Ukraine

schema.headline: Live updates: Donald Trump faces questions at CNN town hall, France investigates death of journalist in Ukraine

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Trump on shakier ground on abortion
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Analysis by North America Correspondent Barbara Miller Julie Miles — an audience member who voted for Trump in 2020 asked the former president how he planned to appeal to women voters concerned about the decision to overturn the federal right to abortion. Concerns among female voters in particular about the stripping away of abortion rights are a tricky issue for Republicans and are thought to have played into the Democrats better than expected results in November's mid-terms. But Donald Trump appears to misunderstand Julie's concerns, describing the Supreme Court's decision as "a great victory", which he personally takes credit for. "I was so honoured to have done it." Fact-check: Donald Trump was no longer in office when the decision was made, but it was likely down to the appointments he made to the Supreme Court while in the White House. Trump says he does believe in exceptions for abortion, if the mother's life is in danger or she was raped. He won't, however, be drawn on whether he'd sign a federal ban on abortion, or give a straight answer on at how many weeks of pregnancy such a ban would be appropriate. The camera pans briefly back to Julie as he speaks, who looks a little confused by the answer.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Audience appears to lap up Trump
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Analysis by North America Correspondent Barbara Miller The New Hampshire audience is apparently made up of Republicans and undecided voters, but you wouldn't know it. There's frequent applause for the President and laughter for his scornful take down of E. Jean Carroll, the woman he was just found to have sexually abused and defamed. "What kind of a woman meets someone… and within minutes you're playing hanky-panky in a dressing room," Donald Trump said. He also appears to suggest that he would not have found a 60 year-old woman attractive. For the record, E. Jean Carroll was in her early 50s when then assault took place.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: If elected, Trump won't be bringing in any new gun restrictions
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A young man who voted for Trump in 2020 asks: "If elected, how would you act to defend gun rights?" "There's no one who has protected the Second Amendment like I have," Trump says, before he begins talking about mental health in America and blaming people, not guns, for gun violence. He then leans into how guns provide Americans with a sense of security.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Beyoncé has dazzled fans at her Renaissance world tour opening concert
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If anyone is worthy of breaking up the Trump news, surely it's Beyoncé? Tens of thousands of fans descended upon the Swedish capital of Stockholm to celebrate the opening show of Beyoncé’s new world tour. Renaissance is the superstar’s first solo tour since 2016 and shares the namesake of her 2022 dance-centric album, the success of which landed Beyoncé at the top of the Grammy throne as the ceremony’s most decorated artist in history. Fans who had complained in recent months about the lack of music videos for Renaissance hits were in for a treat on Wednesday as video projections and animations took center stage.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The challenges of moderating Donald Trump
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Analysis by North America Correspondent Barbara Miller Kaitlin Collins is a rising star at CNN, but this is a huge test for her. How often do you interrupt a former President who continues to spout baseless claims? Here’s another challenge already. Donald Trump says the crowd he spoke to on January 6 2021 was the largest he’s ever spoken to. That would seem on the face of it unlikely, but how important is fact-checking it when Mr Trump is soon back onto claims that the election was not stolen. He also tells the room he’ll pardon many of the rioters jailed in the wake of January 6.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Trump doubles down on stolen election claims
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By North America Correspondent Barbara Miller Straight out the blocks Donald Trump repeats his baseless claim that the 2020 election was stolen. In answer to the first question from moderator Kaitlin Collins as to why Americans should put him back in the White House the President almost immeditately turned to his claims of election fraud. "That was a rigged election and it’s a shame we had to go through it," he said. Kaitlin Collins interrupted the President several times, at one point giving him the option to publicly acknowledge he lost the election, all to no avail. "That was a horrible election," he said "We have to have honest elections." That last comment got warm applause from the audience, who CNN says is made up of Republicans and undeclared voters.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Trump grilled on slow response to January 6 riots
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Why did you wait three hours to tell your supporters to go home on January 6?" asks CNN moderator Kaitlan Collins. Trump points the finger at others. "Nancy Pelosi and the Mayor are in charge and I expect them to do their job," Trump replies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Trump takes first audience question
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: An undecided voter asks: "Will you suspend polarising talk of election fraud during your run?" This question comes a little late, considering Trump has spent the first 5 minutes of this town hall repeating false claims of election fraud. "Unless I see election fraud. If I see it, I’m obligated to say it," Trump responds.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Why did Trump agree to this CNN town hall?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Historically, Donald Trump has a contentious relationship with CNN compared to other outlets. The news network has frequently been a target of the former President’s ire, and even hours before the event, Trump was posting on his own social media platform that it was “a big long term opportunity” for CNN and saying they needed to treat his supporters “with respect”. According to the Associated Press, Trump's team saw the invitation from CNN as an opportunity to connect with a broader swath of voters than those who usually tune into the conservative outlets he favors. "President Trump has been battle-tested and is a proven winner. He doesn’t shy away from anything and faces them head on," said Trump spokesperson Steven Cheung .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: CNN town hall draws criticism
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Emilie Gramenz in Washington, DC CNN, currently struggling with historically low ratings and frequently adjusting its programming schedule, has faced blowback for inviting Donald Trump back on the air. The network has justified it by pointing to the fact that he is currently the leading candidate for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination. “Our job despite his unique circumstances is what we do best,” spokesman Matt Dornic told US media. “Ask tough questions, follow up, and hold him accountable to give voters the information they need to sort through their choices.”

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Protesters have already gathered outside CNN studios
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: CNN's town hall with former US president Donald Trump is due to kick off in about 5 minutes. A small group of anti-Trump protesters have gathered outside the town hall in Manchester, New Hampshire. Their signs included messages like "nobody is above the law" and "elections not insurrection."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's who will be moderating Trump's town hall
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As Felicity reported just earlier, former US president Donald Trump will soon join a CNN town hall in New Hampshire, his first appearance on the network since his 2016 presidential campaign. The current GOP 2024 presidential frontrunner will take questions live from Republican and undecided voters. Interestingly, CNN's Kaitlan Collins (who is only 31!) will be moderating the town hall discussion. Collins, the network's former chief White House correspondent, was known for getting under the former president's skin during his time in office, according to Politico. Trump clashed with Collins several times, both in the briefing room and on Twitter, often after she challenged him for dodging questions or making false claims.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: E Jean Carroll says she's elated at the verdict in her case against Trump
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The former Elle magazine advice columnist says felt "fantastic" after a jury earlier this week found Donald Trump liable for sexually abusing and defaming her. She was awarded $5 million in damages in her civil lawsuit against the former US president. He plans to appeal. The verdict in Manhattan federal court represented a fresh legal setback for Mr Trump as he seeks to regain the presidency in 2024. It also provided vindication for Carroll, 79, who in 2019 publicly accused Trump, 76, of raping her in a Bergdorf Goodman department store dressing room in the mid-1990s. While jurors did not find that Trump raped Carroll, it awarded damages over the incident and over a post last October on Trump's Truth Social platform in which he called Carroll's claim a "complete con job", hoax and lie. It comes ahead of CNN giving Mr Trump a town hall. That will begin in about 20 minutes, and we'll be providing you with updates here .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Fighting continues in Gaza
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Israel says Palestinian militants in Gaza have fired more than 460 rockets at it, amid the heaviest fighting in nine months. Israel's military says that it has responded by hitting more than 130 militant targets in Gaza. Local medics there say six people have been killed and 45 injured. It comes a day after 15 Palestinians were killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza, including three Islamic Jihad leaders.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Coming up: The oppposition will deliver its budget reply tonight
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal government is spending the morning defending it's budget ahead of the opposition delivering its reply tonight. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is expected to back some of the smaller initiatives proposed by the government, and attack others he argues are inflationary. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he's "very very confident" his budget won't add to inflation.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A teenager is facing court after a man was stabbed at a Perth supermarket
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A man has been repeatedly stabbed after going to the aid of a Perth supermarket worker who was allegedly being assaulted by a teenage boy. Police say the female supermarket worker confronted a teenager who was trying to leave the Gosnells store, allegedly without paying for items. The situation escalated and a 39-year-old man tried to intervene to prevent the woman from being assaulted. Police say he was stabbed multiple times and taken to hospital for treatment. A 14-year-old boy has been charged with one count of armed robbery and one count of unlawful wounding. He's due before the Perth Children's Court today.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Google is giving its dominant search engine an artificial-intelligence makeover
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Google has disclosed plans to infuse its dominant search engine with more advanced artificial-intelligence technology, a response to one of the biggest threats to its long-established position as the internet's main gateway. The gradual shift in how Google's search engine runs is rolling out three months after Microsoft's Bing search engine started to tap into technology similar to that which powers the artificially intelligent chatbot ChatGPT. Google has already been testing its own conversational chatbot called Bard. That product, powered by technology called generative AI that also fuels ChatGPT, has only been available to people accepted from a waitlist. But Google announced Wednesday that Bard will be available to all comers in more than 180 countries and more languages beyond English.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The US appeals court has overturned the first of the 'Varsity Blues' scandal convictions
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A US federal appeals court has thrown out the fraud convictions of two wealthy fathers accused of participating in a vast college admissions fraud by conspiring to pay bribes so their children could attend top universities. The 1st US Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston ruled in favour of private equity executive John Wilson and former casino executive Gamal Aziz, the first defendants tried among dozens charged in the sprawling "Operation Varsity Blues" probe. All of Mr Aziz's convictions were set aside, and all but one of Mr Wilson's convictions were aside. The court upheld Wilson's conviction for filing a false tax return.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: News Australians are searching for
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Trump CNN has given the former president a town hall in New Hampshire. The town hall will begin airing in about two hours. He’ll take questions as the frontrunner in the 2024 GOP presidential primary field. It comes just days after he was found liable by a New York jury for sexually abusing magazine columnist E Jean Carroll in the 1990s and defaming her.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The trade minister is visiting China
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Trade Minister Don Farrell is flying to China to press Beijing to lift barriers to Australian exports. He'll meet his Chinese counterpart, Commerce Minister Wang Wentou, as well as other senior officials. Senator Farrell says he'll advocate strongly for the "full resumption of unimpeded Australian exports to China for all sectors". Australian coal has been let back into China and there are signs a dispute over Chinese barley tariffs could be resolved, but there are still formal and informal restrictions on several other products. You can read more here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: There are violent protests in Pakistan
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Pakistan's government has called in the army to help end deadly unrest in the wake of the arrest of former prime minister Imran Khan. Officials have warned protesters against any further attacks on state installations. At least five people have died in violence that has aggravated instability in the South Asian country as it grapples with a severe economic crisis. Khan — Pakistan's most popular political leader according to polls — was arrested in a fraud case on Tuesday, prompting supporters to storm military buildings and ransack the home of a top army general. The government by Wednesday had approved requests from two of Pakistan's four provinces — Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, both Khan strongholds — and the federal capital Islamabad to deploy troops to restore order.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US Republican George Santos has pleaded not guilty to fraud and money laundering
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The New York politician has pleaded not guilty to charges of fraud, money laundering and theft of public funds following his arrest. The indictment says Mr Santos induced supporters to donate to a company under the false pretence that the money would be used to support his campaign. Instead, it says, he used it for personal expenses, including luxury designer clothes and to pay off his credit cards. You can read more here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Outgoing Finnish PM Sanna Marin and husband file for divorce
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Finland's outgoing Prime Minister Sanna Marin has filed for divorce jointly with her husband of three years Markus Raikkonen, they have announced on Instagram. "We are grateful for the 19 years together and our beloved daughter. We will remain best friends," they said in separate Instagram stories. The pair share a 5-year-old daughter and got married in 2020 while Marin was in office dealing with the impact of the pandemic. Marin and her Social Democratic Party lost Finland's election for parliament last month, trailing the right-wing National Coalition Party as well as the nationalist Finns Party. Marin, 37, the world's youngest prime minister when she took office in 2019, is considered by fans around the globe as a millennial role model for progressive new leaders, even as voters at home opted for a new government.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The NRL says Canberra's stadium is no longer fit for purpose
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The National Rugby League has weighed into the debate over a new stadium for Canberra, saying its long overdue. The NRL has made a submission to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital. The NRL says Canberra has lost its appeal as a potential location for rugby league events of national significance. It says Canberra's stadium is no longer fit for purpose and will be overlooked in favour of other venues such as the new Townsville Stadium.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Britain ditches commitment to replace all EU laws by the end of 2023
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The British government has ditched its plan for thousands of EU-era laws to expire automatically at the end of the year. The plan — dubbed a post-Brexit "bonfire" — would see laws that were copied over to the UK after Brexit vanish unless specifically kept or replaced. Critics of the bill had voiced concerns that it could lead to important legislation falling away by accident. The backdown is likely to trigger anger from Brexit-backing Conservative MPs.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The Daily Mirror has apologised to Prince Harry
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The British tabloid newspaper apologised for unlawfully seeking information about the royal. It comes at the start of Prince Harry's lawsuit against the newspaper's publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself. Prince Harry, 38, and about 100 celebrities, are suing publisher Mirror Group Newspapers, accusing its titles of habitually accessing private information by widespread phone hacking, deception and other illicit means between 1991 and 2011. You can read more about the case here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: France is investigating the death of a journalist in Ukraine
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: French authorities have launched an investigation into possible war crimes over the death of a French journalist in Ukraine. Arman Soldin, a video journalist with AFP news agency, was killed by rocket fire near Chasiv Yar in eastern Ukraine earlier this week. Russian forces have been frequently bombing the town over recent weeks. French prosecutors say the investigation will try to establish the exact circumstances of Soldin's death.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A young Australian has won the fifth stage of an Italian cycling race
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Kaden Groves has overcome a late crash to give Australia another success at cycling's Giro d'Italia. The 24-year old Queenslander came down with several other riders in wet conditions with 7km remaining of the fifth stage, but amazingly recovered in time to prevail in a sprint finish. It was his second Grand Tour win after claiming a stage during last year's Tour of Spain, and came just two days after Canberra's Michael Matthews took out stage 3 in Italy. Race favourite Remco Evenepoel of Belgium crashed twice on a day marred by dreadful weather, the first time after a dog strayed on to the road.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A girl has died after a collision with a tram in Sydney
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The pedestrian died after being trapped under the tram in Sydney's CBD overnight. Emergency services were called to the Haymarket light rail station at around midnight after reports of a collision between a girl and a tram. They arrived to find the girl, believed to be in her teens, with critical injuries and she died at the scene.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Fine arts students in Egypt's coastal city of Alexandria are welcoming summer with some creative competition. They've gone head-to-head with their professors in the Sand Sculpture Festival. The event aims to attract visitors to the city's beaches over the warmer months.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The former Elle magazine advice columnist says felt "fantastic" after a jury earlier this week found Donald Trump liable for sexually abusing and defaming her. She was awarded $5 million in damages in her civil lawsuit against the former US president. He plans to appeal. The verdict in Manhattan federal court represented a fresh legal setback for Mr Trump as he seeks to regain the presidency in 2024. It also provided vindication for Carroll, 79, who in 2019 publicly accused Trump, 76, of raping her in a Bergdorf Goodman department store dressing room in the mid-1990s. While jurors did not find that Trump raped Carroll, it awarded damages over the incident and over a post last October on Trump's Truth Social platform in which he called Carroll's claim a "complete con job", hoax and lie. It comes ahead of CNN giving Mr Trump a town hall. That will begin in about 20 minutes, and we'll be providing you with updates here .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A man has been repeatedly stabbed after going to the aid of a Perth supermarket worker who was allegedly being assaulted by a teenage boy. Police say the female supermarket worker confronted a teenager who was trying to leave the Gosnells store, allegedly without paying for items. The situation escalated and a 39-year-old man tried to intervene to prevent the woman from being assaulted. Police say he was stabbed multiple times and taken to hospital for treatment. A 14-year-old boy has been charged with one count of armed robbery and one count of unlawful wounding. He's due before the Perth Children's Court today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Google has disclosed plans to infuse its dominant search engine with more advanced artificial-intelligence technology, a response to one of the biggest threats to its long-established position as the internet's main gateway. The gradual shift in how Google's search engine runs is rolling out three months after Microsoft's Bing search engine started to tap into technology similar to that which powers the artificially intelligent chatbot ChatGPT. Google has already been testing its own conversational chatbot called Bard. That product, powered by technology called generative AI that also fuels ChatGPT, has only been available to people accepted from a waitlist. But Google announced Wednesday that Bard will be available to all comers in more than 180 countries and more languages beyond English.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Google is giving its dominant search engine an artificial-intelligence makeover

The gradual shift in how Google's search engine runs is rolling out three months after Microsoft's Bing search engine started to tap into technology similar to that which powers the artificially intelligent chatbot ChatGPT.
Google has already been testing its own conversational chatbot called Bard.
That product, powered by technology called generative AI that also fuels ChatGPT, has only been available to people accepted from a waitlist.
But Google announced Wednesday that Bard will be available to all comers in more than 180 countries and more languages beyond English.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A US federal appeals court has thrown out the fraud convictions of two wealthy fathers accused of participating in a vast college admissions fraud by conspiring to pay bribes so their children could attend top universities. The 1st US Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston ruled in favour of private equity executive John Wilson and former casino executive Gamal Aziz, the first defendants tried among dozens charged in the sprawling "Operation Varsity Blues" probe. All of Mr Aziz's convictions were set aside, and all but one of Mr Wilson's convictions were aside. The court upheld Wilson's conviction for filing a false tax return.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The US appeals court has overturned the first of the 'Varsity Blues' scandal convictions

props.alt: A man in a blue suit leaves court smiling.

children.content: All of Gamal Aziz's convcitions have been set aside.
(Reuters: Katherine Taylor/File)

A US federal appeals court has thrown out the fraud convictions of two wealthy fathers accused of participating in a vast college admissions fraud by conspiring to pay bribes so their children could attend top universities.

The 1st US Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston ruled in favour of private equity executive John Wilson and former casino executive Gamal Aziz, the first defendants tried among dozens charged in the sprawling "Operation Varsity Blues" probe.
All of Mr Aziz's convictions were set aside, and all but one of Mr Wilson's convictions were aside.
The court upheld Wilson's conviction for filing a false tax return.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Pakistan's government has called in the army to help end deadly unrest in the wake of the arrest of former prime minister Imran Khan. Officials have warned protesters against any further attacks on state installations. At least five people have died in violence that has aggravated instability in the South Asian country as it grapples with a severe economic crisis. Khan — Pakistan's most popular political leader according to polls — was arrested in a fraud case on Tuesday, prompting supporters to storm military buildings and ransack the home of a top army general. The government by Wednesday had approved requests from two of Pakistan's four provinces — Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, both Khan strongholds — and the federal capital Islamabad to deploy troops to restore order.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Finland's outgoing Prime Minister Sanna Marin has filed for divorce jointly with her husband of three years Markus Raikkonen, they have announced on Instagram. "We are grateful for the 19 years together and our beloved daughter. We will remain best friends," they said in separate Instagram stories. The pair share a 5-year-old daughter and got married in 2020 while Marin was in office dealing with the impact of the pandemic. Marin and her Social Democratic Party lost Finland's election for parliament last month, trailing the right-wing National Coalition Party as well as the nationalist Finns Party. Marin, 37, the world's youngest prime minister when she took office in 2019, is considered by fans around the globe as a millennial role model for progressive new leaders, even as voters at home opted for a new government.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The British government has ditched its plan for thousands of EU-era laws to expire automatically at the end of the year. The plan — dubbed a post-Brexit "bonfire" — would see laws that were copied over to the UK after Brexit vanish unless specifically kept or replaced. Critics of the bill had voiced concerns that it could lead to important legislation falling away by accident. The backdown is likely to trigger anger from Brexit-backing Conservative MPs.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Kaden Groves has overcome a late crash to give Australia another success at cycling's Giro d'Italia. The 24-year old Queenslander came down with several other riders in wet conditions with 7km remaining of the fifth stage, but amazingly recovered in time to prevail in a sprint finish. It was his second Grand Tour win after claiming a stage during last year's Tour of Spain, and came just two days after Canberra's Michael Matthews took out stage 3 in Italy. Race favourite Remco Evenepoel of Belgium crashed twice on a day marred by dreadful weather, the first time after a dog strayed on to the road.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysis by North America Correspondent Barbara Miller Kaitlin Collins is a rising star at CNN, but this is a huge test for her. How often do you interrupt a former President who continues to spout baseless claims? Here’s another challenge already. Donald Trump says the crowd he spoke to on January 6 2021 was the largest he’s ever spoken to. That would seem on the face of it unlikely, but how important is fact-checking it when Mr Trump is soon back onto claims that the election was not stolen. He also tells the room he’ll pardon many of the rioters jailed in the wake of January 6.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By North America Correspondent Barbara Miller Straight out the blocks Donald Trump repeats his baseless claim that the 2020 election was stolen. In answer to the first question from moderator Kaitlin Collins as to why Americans should put him back in the White House the President almost immeditately turned to his claims of election fraud. "That was a rigged election and it’s a shame we had to go through it," he said. Kaitlin Collins interrupted the President several times, at one point giving him the option to publicly acknowledge he lost the election, all to no avail. "That was a horrible election," he said "We have to have honest elections." That last comment got warm applause from the audience, who CNN says is made up of Republicans and undeclared voters.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could the budget fuel inflation and rate rises?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's the ongoing debate dominating the economic response to the budget. Both Chris Richardson and Steven Hamilton reckon it will increase inflation, with the possibility of tipping the RBA into another rate rise, if the central bank was on the edge. They spoke to The Business yesterday: But not all economists agree. Former RBA economist and now economics lecturer Zac Gross says the effect on inflation will be negligible. Investment bank Barrenjoey's economics team came up with a similar result from their modelling, as covered by the ABC's Kate Ainsworth :

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Banks, utilities and industrials drag on the ASX
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ASX 200 is trading lower this morning, down just a few points at 7,251. Here's how things are looking as we approach 11am AEST: Leading the charge is lithium miner Allkem which has announced a $US10billion ($14.79billion) merger with US-listed company Livent. The real estate and consumer staples sectors are providing the biggest boost to the ASX.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Graincorp lifts guidance, despite weaker profits
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Agribusiness company GrainCorp has posted lower half year profits but lifted its earnings guidance. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) were $383 million, down from $427 million in the previous corresponding period. Net profit after tax (NPAT) was $200 million, down from $246 million in the first half of 2022. Grancorp lifted its full year guidance: EBITDA of $500- $560 million, up from $470- $530 million. NPAT of $220- $260 million, up from $180- 220 million. GrainCorp's Managing Director and Chief Executive Robert Spurway said there was ongoing demand for Australian grain and oilseeds, supported by a bumper third crop on the east coast. "GrainCorp's export program ran at close to full capacity with 4.4mmt of grain and oilseeds exported during the half," Mr Spurway said. "Export supply chain margins remained solid, albeit not at the levels we saw last year." The company also acknowledged the death of a worker in a fatal truck accident in April at the Graincorp receival site in Moree, New South Wales.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Do the PRRT changes in the budget go far enough to fix a 'broken' Petroleum Resource Rent Tax?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal government will collect $2.4 billion from gas exporters through the PRRT over four years. The gas industry isn't really complaining. According to Treasury, no LNG project has ever paid the tax. Some experts say the government should've gone a lot harder.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Wall street mixed on CPI data and debt ceiling worries
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's some detail about how the US markets ended up overnight: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 30.48 points, or 0.09 per cent, to 33,531. The S & P 500 gained 18.47 points, or 0.4 per cent, at 4,137, while the Nasdaq Composite added 126.89 points, or 1 per cent, at 12,306. The Nasdaq was helped by a 4.1 per cent climb in Google's parent company Alphabet as the company rolled out more artificial intelligence for its core search product in response to competition from Microsoft Corp. Large-cap tech stocks including Apple Inc and Microsoft also gained 1.04 per cent and 1.73 per cent, respectively. The rate-sensitive S & P 500 technology sector index went up 1.2 per cent and the communication services rose 1.69 per cent. Markets reacted positively because they saw the inflation data as a small positive, with hopes rising of a rate pause. "The CPI is indicating some sort of relief in inflationary pressure. That would mean the Fed would be toward the end or already at the end of its interest rate cycle, and growth companies are most heavily affected by higher interest rates," Kevin W. Philip, a partner at investment advisor Bel Air said. Fed funds futures traders are pricing in a pause in rate increases at the central bank's June meeting, and less than a 5 per cent chance of another 25 basis point hike. However, investors also had concerns about the looming US debt ceiling. Talks on raising the US federal government's $US31.4 trillion debt ceiling entered a new phase on Wednesday as some areas of potential compromise emerged after Tuesday's White House meeting. Regional bank shares extended declines from volatile sessions last week on concerns about the sector's health. PacWest Bancorp fell 0.5 per cent, and Zions Bancorporation fell 2.7 per cent respectively. Oil and gas producer Occidental Petroleum Corp fell 3.6 per cent after its first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' estimates. Livent Corp rose 5.2 per cent after Australian lithium miner Allkem Ltd agreed to merge with the US-based chemical manufacturing firm to create a $US10.6 billion firm. Airbnb Inc 10.9 per cent as the vacation rental booking company had fewer bookings and lower average daily rates in the second quarter. Rivian Automotive jumped 1.8 per cent after the electrical vehicle maker beat estimates for its first-quarter results and reiterated its annual production forecast. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US annual inflation slows to 4.9 per cent
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: US consumer prices slowed to below 5 per cent in April for the first time in two years, lifting hopes of an interest rate pause. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.4 per cent last month after gaining 0.1 per cent in March. The increase was in line with economists' expectations, according to Reuters. Stubbornly high rents accounted for much of the increase in inflation. However, there were pockets of relief for consumers. Food prices were unchanged for a second straight month. Grocery store prices fell 0.2 per cent after decreasing 0.3 per cent in March, posting back-to-back declines for the first time since July 2019. Fruits and vegetables, meat, fish and eggs were cheaper compared to March. Milk prices dropped 2 per cent. Natural gas prices tumbled 4.9 per cent and the cost of electricity dropped for the second straight month, blunting some of the 3 per cent jump in gasoline prices, which followed a 4.6 per cent plunge in March. The rebound came after Saudi Arabia and other OPEC+ oil producers announced further oil output cuts. Annual inflation increased 4.9 per cent, which was the smallest yearly rise since April 2021. - with Reuters

image.altText: Jess and Jackie Morecroft stand in the driveway of their home.

items.synopsis: After a five-year court battle, the Morecrofts lost their Gold Coast family home. Now they're facing legal costs that could financially ruin them.

title.children: Couple told they never owned house they paid for 'at wits' end' over order to pay legal costs

image.altText: A picture of a vegetable garden in the fore, with woman gardener in the picture

items.synopsis: It clogs up drains, sticks to your hairbrush, and no one wants it in their food, but hair is great for cleaning up oil spills and, when broken down, could improve your garden.

title.children: Human hair could be the ultimate recycled product as fertiliser or cleaning oil spills

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: The chair of the panel investigating racism allegations at Hawthorn says coaches refuse to be interviewed until they have seen documents which First Nations players say contain personal and sensitive information.

title.children: Review over racism claims at Hawthorn stalls over access to documents

image.altText: A woman in an Imran Khan face mask, sunglasses and a headscarf raises an arm

items.synopsis: Pakistan's political crisis has worsened, stoking divisions in society, leading to extreme polarisation and the violent reactions we've seen this week, writes Zahid Shahab Ahmed.

title.children: Why Pakistan is on a knife edge — and fiery protests are expected to get worse

image.altText: A young blonde girl smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Fourteen-year-old Shyanne-Lee Tatnell has not been seen or heard from since April 30. Now community members are getting involved in the search to find her.

title.children: Shyanne-Lee disappeared in Launceston 10 days ago, without a phone call or sighting since

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shirt and hat sits on a macadamia machine harvesting nuts.

items.synopsis: The majority of Australian macadamia processors will pay their suppliers some of the lowest prices on record, with concerns they could drop further.

title.children: Macadamia growers face financial disaster as glut drives prices down

image.altText: An image of a microscope above a petri dish with some fluid in it.

items.synopsis: Britain's fertility regulator on Wednesday confirmed the births of the UK's first babies created using an experimental technique combining DNA from three people, an effort to prevent the children from inheriting rare genetic diseases.

title.children: In UK first, babies are being born using three people's DNA in an effort to prevent rare genetic diseases

image.altText: Man in diving gear touching the mouth of a large whale shark underwater.

items.synopsis: Making a natural history documentary is a test of patience and endurance, and Tim Winton had finally run out of both. He was trying to capture the wild beauty of his beloved Ningaloo Reef but Mother Nature wouldn't play ball.

title.children: Tim Winton picked parasites off whale shark's mouth, but that's not what 'terrified' him

image.altText: Kaden Groves (right in blue) extends his arms after crossing the finish line on sage five of the Giro d'Italia.

items.synopsis: Australian Kaden Groves bounces back after getting caught up in a rainy stage littered with crashes, with Remco Evenepoel brought down multiple times.

title.children: Stray dog brings down Giro d'Italia race favourite as Australian wins crash-ridden stage 5

image.altText: A dark-haired woman looks at her young daughter, who's facing her in a swing

items.synopsis: Tasmanians are waiting years instead of days to access vital ear, nose and throat specialist appointments. The Department of Health is trying to find a solution.

title.children: Girl, 7, who 'can't eat properly' set for a six-year wait to get tonsils out

image.altText: A young boy in navy sitting in his wheelchair on the concrete edge of Brennan Park.

items.synopsis: One-fifth of the region is living with a disability, so why would a community park makeover leave some unable to play? This seven-year-old who uses a wheelchair is asking council to reconsider.

title.children: Zach loved playing in Brennan Park until council upgraded it, leaving him on the outer

image.altText: An Australian progressive metal group pose for the camera in a corridor backstage at the venue for the Eurovision Song Contest.

items.synopsis: Perth progressive metal band Voyager are finally achieving their dream to make Eurovision history, as the first group to represent Australia — they talk to ABC about the long road to the Contest, the songs that didn't quite make it, their Spinal Tap moment in Amsterdam, and more.

title.children: From Runaway to Dreamer to Promise, how Voyager finally made it to Eurovision

image.altText: Alexander Skarsgård, a white man with blonde hair is wearing sunglasses and a white striped shirt. He has cuts on his face.

items.synopsis: Following in his filmmaker father’s footsteps and riffing off the success of White Lotus and Triangle of Sadness, Brandon Cronenberg has made a stomach-churning holiday horror with Infinity Pool.

title.children: This sci-fi horror starring Alexander Skarsgård is an orgiastic feast that will make you squirm
